DOCNAME: CASE OF JAN-AKE ANDERSSON v. SWEDEN
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , a NORP citizen , is an engineer by profession and resides in ORG in the LOC - West of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was stopped by police inspector B. while driving a tractor on a highway ( motortrafikled ) , on which this was prohibited under the Traffic Ordinance of DATE ( vägtrafikkungörelsen ORG the DATE LAW ) . He refused to pay a fine , maintaining that he had not seen any road sign indicating the category of the road or the prohibition in question .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON was summoned to appear before ORG ( tingsrätten ) of ORG , charged with having contravened sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Ordinance .

In a letter to ORG he stated that he expected the public prosecutor to call certain police officers , including police inspector PERSON , as witnesses , as he could not afford to call any himself . Moreover , the public prosecutor should , he said , produce the relevant official meteorological records ( see the extracts from ORG judgment in paragraph CARDINAL below ) . In addition , he requested ORG to appoint an official defence counsel .

On DATE this request was refused by ORG , which considered that the case was simple and that the applicant was able to defend himself . His appeal against this decision was dismissed by ORG ( hovrätten ) of GPE and PERSON on DATE , with no possibility of further appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing ( huvudförhandling ) during which both the applicant and police inspector B. were heard . It did not , however , order the production of the relevant meteorological records . On DATE it found the applicant guilty of the charge brought against him and sentenced him to a fine of MONEY . In its judgment ORG stated :

" [ The applicant ] has contested criminal liability and has made the following statement : He was on his way from ORG to ORG driving a tractor that he had just bought . He had travelled with his father to ORG that morning and they had then , inter alia , travelled the same road but in the opposite direction . The mist had been very dense already in the morning and [ the applicant ] had observed nothing special as regards the road during the trip . He does not know what the concept ‘ ORG means . When he arrived on the ‘ ORG west of ORG it was so misty that he saw no road signs that attracted his attention . He was therefore unaware of the character of the road he was driving on and even if he had noticed a road sign indicating ‘ ORG he would not have known what restrictions this would imply as regards driving certain vehicles .
Police inspector B. has been heard as a witness but has not given any information other than that the weather was normal in the area of ORG without any signs of mist .

[ The applicant ] - who was driving as alleged by the public prosecutor - drove a long distance by tractor and should therefore have paid particular attention to the rules applicable as regards the driving of such a vehicle . The fact that the weather was misty does not relieve him from his obligations as a driver . He shall therefore be convicted in accordance with the charge against him . "

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG of GPE and PERSON . He claimed that the proceedings before ORG had been " unbalanced " and that numerous " interruptions " by the judge had prevented him from following the arguments and from presenting his case in a satisfactory manner ; that the fine imposed was far too high ; and furthermore , that ORG had overlooked the fact that certain road signs had been missing .

In his reply of DATE , the public prosecutor , referring to the evidence submitted before ORG , maintained that the applicant was guilty and expressed the opinion that it was not necessary to hold a new hearing . On DATE ORG sent a copy of this reply to the applicant , advising him that since the case could be adjudicated without a new hearing , he was entitled to submit final written observations within DATE .

In his final observations of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON asked ORG to take the absence of certain road signs into account and to consider the weather situation and the fact that he was overtaken by an unmarked police car which failed to warn him .

He also applied for a public hearing to be held in GPE , for police inspector B. to be heard as a witness and for the relevant meteorological records to be examined . In addition , he requested free legal assistance since he needed defence counsel and did not have sufficient means to pay for CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . ORG rejected the applicant ’s requests and decided the case on the basis of the case - file . In its judgment of DATE , upholding the findings of ORG , it stated :

" From the photos which have been referred to , it appears that the fact that the road in question was a ‘ ORG did appear from appropriate and visible road signs at ORG . For this reason and since [ the applicant ] nevertheless drove the tractor on [ the road ] from PERSON to GPE , he committed the offence with which he has been charged by the prosecution . "

CARDINAL . PERSON applied for leave to appeal to ORG ( högsta domstolen ) , claiming that the appeal proceedings had been very " unbalanced " and had not complied with human - rights standards . ORG refused the application on DATE .

CARDINAL . Under the rules on public access to official documents , contained in the Freedom of the Press Act DATE ( tryckfrihetsförordningen ) and LAW ( sekretesslagen , CARDINAL ) , the case - files from the courts involved were all accessible to the public .

CARDINAL . According to LAW of LAW , lower courts must not as a rule give judgment in criminal cases until the accused has been able to defend himself at an oral hearing . Exceptions to this rule do , however , exist , particularly at appellate level . Thus , LAW , section DATE , as worded at the relevant time ( it was subsequently amended with effect from DATE ) , provided :
" ORG may decide the case without a hearing if the prosecutor appeals only for the benefit of the accused or if an appeal lodged by the accused is supported by the opposing party .

The case may be decided without a hearing if the lower court has acquitted the accused or discharged the offender or found him to be exempted from punishment by virtue of mental abnormality or if it has sentenced him to a fine or ordered him to pay a money penalty ( vite ) and there is no reason to impose a more severe sanction than those mentioned above or to impose any other sanction ... "

CARDINAL . ORG has the power to review questions both of law and of fact . However , there are some limits to its jurisdiction . LAW , for instance , lays down that ORG may not normally change the lower court ’s assessment of the evidence to the disadvantage of the accused without the evidence in question being produced afresh before ORG ; LAW , LAW ( as amended by LAW and CARDINAL ) also contains a rule prohibiting the appellate court , in cases where the appeal is lodged by the accused or by the prosecutor for the benefit of the accused , from imposing a sentence which can be considered more severe than that imposed at first instance .
